abstract.p: Letter from Douglas Lasdon (Urban Justice Center), commenting on March 28 article, says New York City's legal obligation to children discharged from foster care extends to age 21, not 18, if they become homeless

block.p: In a March 28 front-page article describing the difficulties youths face upon discharge from foster care, you repeat the myth that the city's legal obligation ends when they reach 18. In response to a 1985 lawsuit by the Urban Justice Center, New York State passed a regulatory program that prohibits discharging youths until age 21 to ''independent living, unless the child has a residence.'' If ''the child becomes homeless,'' the district ''must assist the child to obtain housing.''

In a March 28 front-page article describing the difficulties youths face upon discharge from foster care, you repeat the myth that the city's legal obligation ends when they reach 18. In response to a 1985 lawsuit by the Urban Justice Center, New York State passed a regulatory program that prohibits discharging youths until age 21 to ''independent living, unless the child has a residence.'' If ''the child becomes homeless,'' the district ''must assist the child to obtain housing.''

In 1985 the city discharged Reggie Brown, a plaintiff in the lawsuit, from foster care at age 18 to a shelter for homeless men. In 1987, struggling to survive while living in a burned-out building, he was shot and killed. You do a disservice to his memory by ignoring the changes in the law that came about because of his efforts.
DOUGLAS LASDON Exec. Dir., Urban Justice Center New York, March 28, 2000
